content.description:
SDS in a scoop with numerous shallow huceos and lieback up and left into a gritty thin crack. Descend the backside with what's left of your skin.

Mistakenly listed as being on the Marley Boulder in the Joshua Tree bouldering guide.
content.location:
East side of the boulder just around from

Pinto

.

content.description:
This slightly harder twin to

Pinto

goes from a high first hold up the near-vertical face on mostly good edges and the odd sloper.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
5' right of

Pinto

at a black patch of lichen and a high first hold.

content.description:
Climb

Palomino

to the sloping dish then traverse left on a sloping rail with smears for the feet. Match on the far left then move up using a left hand pinch and right hand edge. A little gritty but the moves are enjoyable.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
Weave your way up the left side of the near-vertical face following the path of least resistance and enjoy the featured holds. Quality.
content.location: Left side of the northeast face.

content.description: Smear your feet high to reach an overhead sloping dish, match and then run your feet up the smooth face until possible to mantle up.
content.location: Right side of the northeast face.

content.description:
Interesting moves lead up the sculpted arete passing a flowerpot jug for the left hand and on to the top. A bit grainy but it should clean up with more traffic.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Right edge of the northeast face.
